label: John Locke Institute Essay Competition
title: Existential Threat: Antimicrobial Resistance
description: In this essay, "existential threat" and "existential risk" are both used for the same definition. "Existential threat" is mostly used for casual acknowledgment, while "existential risk" is mostly used for theories and definitions from academic sources. Also, in this essay, we are mostly discussing antibiotic resistance, one common type of antimicrobial resistance. However, other types of antimicrobial resistance are also highly related. Therefore, since 'AMR' is the general name, this essay will use the term "AMR" more often.
prompt: Which existential threat are humans underestimating?

label: International Journal of Social Science and Human Research (IJSSHR)
title: Internet Use and Political Participation: An Empirical Study of Beijing
description: IJSSHR is a peer-reviewed, open-access international journal covering the social sciences and humanities, offering a platform for multidisciplinary research (e.g., sociology, political science, education, culture).
prompt: This paper uses a quantitative empirical approach to analyse how internet use influences political participation among residents in Beijing, examining online information acquisition, social media use, and political behaviour (such as voting, public affairs discussion) and their interrelations.

label: IB History Extended Essay
title: Carl Diem: The Epitome of an Ideological Clash in the Olympics
description: Explores how Carl Diem, the organiser of the 1936 Berlin Olympics, displayed both Nazi and Olympic values throughout his career and discusses his actual stance between two ideologies.
prompt: To what extent was Carl Diem an upholder of Olympism instead of Nazism from 1899 to 1952?
